bibl.title: Ichitaro Akagi v. Luther Weedin. Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS
IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLICATION OFAKAGI, ICHITARO, For Writ of Habeas Corpus
AKAGI, ICHITARO, Petitioner vs. LUTHER WEEDIN, Commissioner of Immigration, Respondent
Comes now Ichitaro Akagi, by his attorney, Winter S. Martin, and respectfully shows to the Court:

That your petitioner is a citizen of the Empire of Japan, who came to the United States on board the Japanese Steamer, "Eastern Glen", arriving at the Port of Seattle, on May 9th, 1920, as a seaman on said boat.

That on the day of his arrival your petitioner deserted his said ship at the Port of Seattle, and thereafter remained in the United States and in the State of Washington until he was arrested and taken into custody as hereinafter set forth.
That on the 31st day of January, 1922 a warrant for his arrest was issued by the Department of Labor on the ground that he was a laborer unlawfully in the United States without a passport

in violation of Rule 11 and the Presidential Proclomation of February 24th, 1913, and that he was person likely to become a public charge at the time of entry. That on said day your peti- tioner was arrested and taken into custody by the Immigration Officers of the United States at the Port of Seattle where he since has been and now is, to-wit, at the United States Immigra- tion Station at Seattle aforesaid.

That thereafter by Departmental Order of February 25th, 1922, your petitioner was ordered deported to the Empire of Japan upon a ship which will leave the Port of Seattle at 10:00 o'clock A.M. March 4th, 1922, to-wit, tomorrow morning. That the grounds for deportation are that your petitioner is a Japanese laborer, who is and was unlawfully in the United States without a passport, and that he was a person likely to become a public charge, all in violation of the President's proclomation and the Immigration Laws and Rules in that particular provided.

That your petitioneer alleges that Rule 11 of the Immigra- tion Rules adopted and promulgated on May 1, 1917, do not apply to petitioner in and for the reason and the President's Proclomation of February 24th, 1913 only touches and applies to those alien laborers, who have and had passports limited to some Country or place other than the Continental United States, and who seek to enter the United States from said Country; that is to say that said proclomation does not touch or reach persons coming directly into the United States from the Empire of Japan, and that there is no law requiring a laborer or any other person coming directly from Japan to the United States to have a passport;

That in addition to the matters and things hereinbefore alleged, your petitioner alleges that the American Consul at the Port of departure upon the voyage upon which petitioner entered the United States, visaed the crew list of said ship. That your petition- er was a seaman member of said ship, duly entered upon her Articles. That in visaing the crew list your petitioner was not required by law to have any other or further passport to enter the United States. That as a seaman he was entitled to enter the United States and be and remain in the United States until he had taken ship to other Ports or places in the world. That deportation is not sought in this case upon any of said grounds.

That by reason of the premises your petitioner is illegally restrained from his liberty by Luther Weedin and his deputies, officers and inspectors of the United States Immigration Service at the Port of Seattle. That said Weedin and said officers are threaten- ing to deport your petitioner herewith. That unless said Weedin and said Immigration Officers, deputies and inspectors are enjoined by order of this Court, they will execute their threat and your petitioner will be deported to the Empire of Japan and be without relief.
1. That a Writ of Habeas Corpus may be issued to your said petitioner and that he may be discharged from said illegal restraint and unlawful arrest;
2. That pending a hearing upon an application for this Writ of Habeas Corpus that said Luther Weedin, Commissioner of Immigration, and his deputies, be hereby enjoined and restrained
from deporting your petitioner from Seattle to the Empire of Japan;

3. That an order show cause issue forthwith directed to the said Luther Weedin, Commissioner of Immigration, requiring him to be and appear in the above entitled Court, at a time to be fixed by this Honorable Court, to show cause, if any he has,
State of Washington County of King

AKAGI, ICHITARO being first duly sworn on oath says: That he is the Petitioner in the above entitled action; that he has had the foregoing petition read to him by an interperter knows the contents thereof and believes the same to be true.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 3rd day of March 1922
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle, Washington
In the United States District Court FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON
IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLI-? CATION OF AKAGI, ICHITARO,
FOR A WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS
Petition for A Writ of Habeas Corpus
FILED IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
Copy of within petition received and due service of the same acknowl- edged this day of March 1922
Service of all subsequent papers in the within named action, except writs and pro- cess, may be made upon by serving the same upon the udnersigned, as
for said at 704 New York Block, Seattle, Washington.
